confession.devil_appearance: First appeared as strange animal like a hare, later as a black cat in stable
confession.seduction_date: 14 years before trial (1601), when she married and came to Docelles
confession.seduction_context: Taking cart to woods before dawn; devil appeared as a boy who sympathized with her harsh treatment by husband, promised money (gave her a copper jeton instead of a franc). He asked her to stay with him and renounce God. She wore a cross which made him disappear.
powder_types: powder made from herbs the devil had shown her
sabbat_activities: Many people present but all masked
Transported sometimes by devil, sometimes on foot, sometimes in a whirlwind

testimony.quarrel_subject: Refused to give Fleuratte 'semences de pourceaux' (pig feed/grain), saying she only had enough for herself
testimony.threat_quote: Fleuratte said something she didn't understand after being refused grain

testimony.quarrel_subject: Fleuratte and her husband begged witness's husband (a forester) to mark some trees for them; he refused until they had an assignat from the Sieurs Gruyers et Controleurs d'Arches
Wife Jannon had a dispute with Fleuratte

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: shortly after she came to house (9-10 years before)

harms_alleged.target: Mongeote (daughter, wife of Jean Jacot Gegoulf)
harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: next day after Fleuratte touched her

testimony.quarrel_subject: Dispute over price of a hive; Fleuratte's bees were attacking and killing his bees
testimony.threat_quote: Witness threatened to kill Fleuratte if she did not stop her bees attacking his

testimony.quarrel_subject: Witness's son quarrelled with Jean Maurice's daughter while guarding animals
After 'quelque discorde', he told Fleuratte it was a common belief she was a witch; her husband became angry and threatened to attack them
He had quarrelled with her twice

Dispute over payment for carpenter work; Jean Maurice had received a loaf valued at 8 gros 8 deniers in part payment. Fleuratte came asking for outstanding money, but witness said husband was away. Dispute followed over exact value of loaves.
testimony.threat_quote: que pour huit deniers ils se pourroient retrouver ailleurs

testimony.quarrel_subject: Husband called Jean Maurice's daughter 'fille de genaxe' after she said she knew a herb with which she could render him and others present quite naked
Had been in habit of cooking bread in Maurice's oven; after a couple of occasions when baking went wrong, had gone elsewhere

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: after they stopped using her oven

witnesses.name: Claudon Mongin
witnesses.occupation: moictrier (miller/tenant farmer) at Claudon Andreu's grange at Sebarup

testimony.quarrel_subject: Fleuratte asked if he would cook his bread at her house as usual, but he said that as he had his horse he would take flour home
testimony.threat_quote: que c'estoit un meschant homme et qu'elle luy feroit bien paroistre; qu'il faisoit courir le bruit qu'elle auroit fait mourir son cheval, et qu'il se pouvoit assurer qu'il s'en repentiroit

harms_alleged.time_after_quarrel: same day after Fleuratte touched it
next day after Fleuratte visited and asked about calf

timeline.subject: PG des Vosges
timeline.details: Orders given by PG des Vosges

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Prévôt of Bruyères has summoned witnesses to testify

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Beginning of preliminary informations with 19 witness depositions

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Curious confession made by accused at château - described encounter with strange animal/devil

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Normal interrogation; she confessed to pact with devil calling himself 'Persin ou petit chouchoux'

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Further interrogation; denied specific pact or sabbat attendance; PG des Vosges calls for death sentence and torture to elicit accomplices

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Confrontations with witnesses; she generally denied serious points

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: After confrontations, weeping and contrite, confessed to being a witch for 14 years, attending sabbat, and various malefices

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Further interrogation; denied any other malefices or identifying those at sabbat

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Still unable to name accomplices; said devil never gave her grease or powder

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Change de Nancy approves death sentence and torture

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Tortured to obtain names of accomplices; given thumbscrews and racked; identified Curien Simonin of bois de Mortagne

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Prévôt de Bruyeres assembled 'bons hommes de la prévôté' who passed sentence to burn alive

timeline.subject: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
timeline.details: Burned alive; maintained at execution that Curien Simonin had been at sabbat

timeline.subject: Curien Simonin
timeline.details: Order from PG des Vosges for investigation of Curien Simonin

accomplices_named.name: Curien Simonin
accomplices_named.context: Identified under torture as having been at sabbat; described as being of 'haulte stature'

prior_accusations.context: Had been suspected of witchcraft before she left Bonmesnil where she had been married

notable_quotes.speaker: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
notable_quotes.french: tu reviens bien souvent meschante beste, et qu'il repartit pourquoy il ne reviendroit pas, et ell replique va t'en et ne reviens jamais
notable_quotes.english: You come back very often, wicked beast, and he replied why would he not come back, and she replied go away and never come back
notable_quotes.context: Speaking to the devil who appeared as a black cat in her stable

notable_quotes.speaker: Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot
notable_quotes.french: que pour huit deniers ils se pourroient retrouver ailleurs
notable_quotes.english: That for eight deniers they could find each other elsewhere
notable_quotes.context: Threat made by Fleuratte after dispute over bread payment

notable_quotes.speaker: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice (healing prayer)
notable_quotes.french: Jehennon de toutes airs que tu as prinse, dieu et la Vierge Marie et Monsieur Saint Desair te puisse guerir de toutes airs, au nom de pere, du fils, et du Saint Esprit
notable_quotes.english: Jehennon of all airs that you have taken, God and the Virgin Mary and Monsieur Saint Desair may cure you of all airs, in the name of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit
notable_quotes.context: Magical prayer she used to heal people 'prinses de l'air et mal de teste'

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Demengeon
notable_quotes.french: que personne du village ne fait banquet de nopces ou autre sans luy envoier quelque present de chair ou autre vivres
notable_quotes.english: No one in the village holds a wedding banquet or other without sending her some present of meat or other food
notable_quotes.context: Describing how feared Fleuratte was in the community

notable_quotes.speaker: Nicolas Mairote
notable_quotes.french: Au surplus comme chacun la redoubte, cela fait par consequent qu'a qui mieux on luy donne de la paste outre l'ordinaire
notable_quotes.english: Moreover, as everyone fears her, this consequently means that people vie with each other to give her dough beyond the ordinary
notable_quotes.context: Describing community fear and attempts to appease Fleuratte

notable_quotes.speaker: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice
notable_quotes.french: qu'il faudroit bien les biens de trois pareiles villages que celuy de Docelles pour la faire prendre
notable_quotes.english: It would take the wealth of three villages like Docelles to have her arrested
notable_quotes.context: Fleuratte's boast about her power and immunity

notable_quotes.speaker: Claudon Mongin
notable_quotes.french: que c'estoit un meschant homme et qu'elle luy feroit bien paroistre
notable_quotes.english: That he was a wicked man and she would make him see it
notable_quotes.context: Threat made by Fleuratte after being accused of killing his horse

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Miche
notable_quotes.context: Comment by Fleuratte about horse drinking at pool; horse died 2 days later

relationships.evidence_text: Fleuratte femme Jean Maurice, de Docelles; Jean Maurice was a carpenter
First marriage was to Claudon Houatte of Grandviller
Had 8 children by first marriage, only two girls aged 18 and 17 still alive
Her father, Bernard Rouyer, had come from Essey
Her mother Marguerite Alix Thomas, from St Maurice
Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin de Docelles
Claudatte femme Mengel Barbay de Docelles
Nicolle veuve Mathieu Aubry de Docelles; husband died in 8 days
Jacote veuve Mathieu Marion de Docelles
Her daughter Mongeote, wife of Jean Jacot Gegoulf
Her daughter Mongeote, wife of Jean Jacot Gegoulf
Yolent femme honorable Hilaire Mirpot, tabellion de Docelles
Anne femme Didier Villaume de Docelles
Jannon femme Nicolas Estienne de Docelles
Claudate veuve Jean Nancey de Docelles
Judith veuve Mongeon Jean Jacot de Docelles; death of husband 10 years earlier
Claudon Mongin moictrier a Claudon Andreu de Docelles en sa grange de Sebarup
His wife Jannon had a dispute with Fleuratte

economic_context.details: Multiple economic tensions: Jean Maurice was a carpenter who did work for villagers; disputes over payment for carpenter work (Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot); requests for forestry favors (marking trees); use of Maurice's oven for baking bread (multiple witnesses); disputes over bee hives and honey; Fleuratte's father 'pour n'avoir guieres de moyen' (for not having much means) lived as a tenant farmer. Community members feared to exclude Fleuratte from economic activities (weddings, oven use) lest they suffer harm. Witness 11 noted 'personne du village ne fait banquet de nopces ou autre sans luy envoier quelque present de chair ou autre vivres' - no one held a feast without sending her food.

harms_catalog.victim_name: Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Great pain in stomach, became so ill some thought it was mortal; described as 'prise de l'air'
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to give Fleuratte 'semences de pourceaux' (pig feed), saying she only had enough for herself
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Words - Fleuratte said something witness didn't understand when they met

harms_catalog.victim_name: cow belonging to Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Cow died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Same as above - refusal of grain
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: a few days after witness sought cure from Fleuratte
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Part of cure ritual - cow tethered in place where witness was to perform ritual died

harms_catalog.victim_name: Elder daughter of Judith (aged about 15)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Death after illness
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Poison in wine - Fleuratte confessed to putting powder made from herbs the devil showed her in wine

harms_catalog.victim_name: Two oxen belonging to Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became sick
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness had published that Fleuratte knew bad arts and had been first to defame her of sorcery
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Fleuratte's daughter (Jennon) entered stable where oxen were; they recovered after her visit

harms_catalog.victim_name: Jacote (married daughter of Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Died after illness; fell into extase/trance after Fleuratte visited
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: the Sunday after Fleuratte visited and gave her honey
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Poisoned honey - 'they believed Fleuratte had hastened the end of her days by the honey she gave her'

harms_catalog.victim_name: Chambermaid of Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became indisposed with the illness mentioned in deposition
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Touch - Fleuratte touched her on the shoulder, calling her 'la grosse demersale'

harms_catalog.victim_name: Son of Jean Thouvelin (aged 2)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Died after three week illness
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: 3 days after Fleuratte was in his house

harms_catalog.victim_name: Mathieu Aubry (husband, forester)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill with exceptionally painful foot, became 'comme demoniacle' (like possessed), died in 8 days
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to mark trees for Fleuratte and husband until they had an assignat from the Sieurs Gruyers et Controleurs d'Arches

harms_catalog.victim_name: Cow belonging to Jean Jacat Demenge
harms_catalog.harm_description: Died suddenly in fields
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Wife Jannon had a dispute with Fleuratte and called her a witch

harms_catalog.victim_name: Small child of Jean Jacat Demenge
harms_catalog.harm_description: Died; Fleuratte had walked around fire saying nothing but that she had a bad finger
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Difficult to satisfy while cooking in her oven
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Proximity and gesture - walking around fire

harms_catalog.victim_name: Mongeote (daughter, wife of Jean Jacot Gegoulf)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Was in such pain that she cried for three days and nights; became so ill mother had to fetch her home from fête
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: next day after Fleuratte passed hand over her head and made comment about shirt
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Touch - passing hand over head; words about shirt being in one piece

harms_catalog.victim_name: All bees belonging to Demenge Miche
harms_catalog.harm_description: All his bees died after Fleuratte's bees stopped attacking his
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Disagreement over price of a hive; her bees had been attacking and killing his; he threatened to kill her if she didn't stop them
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: after threat and bees stopped attacking

harms_catalog.victim_name: Horse belonging to Demenge Miche
harms_catalog.harm_description: Horse died
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Words - Fleuratte passed and said his horse was drinking 'a un beau goublet'

harms_catalog.victim_name: Son of Didier Villaume
harms_catalog.harm_description: Boy became ill
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Son had quarrelled with Jean Maurice's daughter while guarding animals; Fleuratte came to complain and father beat the boy to satisfy her

harms_catalog.victim_name: Various animals belonging to Nicolas Estienne
harms_catalog.harm_description: Loss of various animals

harms_catalog.victim_name: Grandson of Mongel Barbay (aged about 18 months)
harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell ill

harms_catalog.victim_name: Horse belonging to Nicolas Demengeon
harms_catalog.harm_description: Horse killed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He had twice quarrelled with her

harms_catalog.victim_name: 5-year-old daughter of Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot
harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost use of limbs and even her speech
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Dispute over payment for carpenter work; exact value of loaves (8 gros 8 deniers vs 8 gros)
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Words - threat 'que pour huit deniers ils se pourroient retrouver ailleurs'

harms_catalog.victim_name: Hen belonging to Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot
harms_catalog.harm_description: Hen sickened and died as child recovered
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Transfer - hen used as 'vive offrande' to Bel Bernard died as child recovered

harms_catalog.victim_name: Dog belonging to Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot
harms_catalog.harm_description: Dog became rabid and had to be killed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Witness got rid of Fleuratte as well as she could, being greatly afraid; their shepherdess had called Fleuratte's daughter's mother a witch

harms_catalog.victim_name: Ox belonging to Nicolas Mairote
harms_catalog.harm_description: Ox died
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Had stopped using Maurice's oven for baking after a couple of occasions when baking went wrong

harms_catalog.victim_name: Ox belonging to Jannon femme Nicolas Estienne
harms_catalog.harm_description: Ox died

harms_catalog.victim_name: Horse belonging to Claudon Mongin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Lost use of its back legs, had to be killed
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: Refused to cook bread at her house as usual, said he would take flour home since he had his horse
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Touch - Fleuratte came to stable, 'apres l'avoir longtemps consideré' (after looking at it for a long time) touched it

harms_catalog.victim_name: Claudon Mongin
harms_catalog.harm_description: Fell sick with illness he still had; body sometimes swelled up, had to go to bed and warm himself
harms_catalog.precipitating_quarrel: He had been spreading word that she had killed his horse; she threatened him 'qu'il se pouvoit assurer qu'il s'en repentiroit' (he could be sure he would regret it)

harms_catalog.victim_name: Young bull belonging to Claudate veuve Jean Nancey
harms_catalog.harm_description: Became ill, blind and trembling; expert said it was an unknown illness 'et qu'il tenoit qu'il estoit ensorcelé' (bewitched); died 5 or 6 days later
harms_catalog.time_between_quarrel_and_harm: next day after Fleuratte came into house and asked if their calf had returned from field
harms_catalog.method_alleged: Proximity and question about the animal; when called to cure, made sign of cross with left hand

Jean Maurice's oven used by villagers for baking bread
Ground at mill, taken to Maurice's house for baking
Ferns/bracken that Fleuratte pretended to cut

To be burned in church for the dead
Fleuratte confessed to putting this in wine to kill daughter

Where Claudon Mongin was coming down from to mill corn
Where Fleuratte was sent to fetch estelles; where devil first appeared; where carpenters worked on bridge
Where animals grazed; where cow died suddenly; where children guarded animals
Where carpenters were working
Where Demenge Miche was watering his horse when Fleuratte made comment
Where Fleuratte told witness to throw dead hen
Where Fleuratte made confession on October 4th
Where Fleuratte met devil a week after first encounter
Unspecified; Fleuratte claimed to attend but could recognize no one as all were masked
Where devil appeared as black cat; where animals were kept and harmed

economic_hardship_indicators: Fleuratte's father 'pour n'avoir guieres de moyen' (for not having much means)
Fleuratte's husband treated her like a servant, sending her to woods at all hours
Multiple instances of disputes over small amounts (8 deniers)
Economic tensions over use of oven, payment for services
Fear of economic exclusion from community events
religious_calendar_references: le soir de caresme entrant (evening of Lent beginning)

officials_named.name: Sr. Pilot, valet de chambre de S.A.

legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Held at château where she made confession on October 4th

hearsay_chains.content: Told him that Fleuratte had said she could have cured his child
Fleuratte had advised them to make a pilgrimage
Fleuratte reproached her that she had been to testify against her yesterday
Fleuratte had told their servant that it was well they had acted quickly

emotional_state_notes: Apres avoir longtemps varié, se beaucoup contristé, et fait la pleureuse (after varying for a long time, being very distressed, and playing the weeper)
Showed no reaction when told it was common belief she was a witch (witness 10)
Her husband was angry and made show of attacking those who called her witch

reproaches_to_witnesses.objection: Agreed to asking for money from Jean Thouvenin, but it had been 'paisiblement' (peacefully)
Agreed to testimony except that she had not made child ill, and had not advised throwing hen in the river
Claimed that Mengin Barbay and Nicolas Demengeon had called her witch after making a wager, and that it would not have happened if her husband had been willing to defend her
Reproached Jannon that she had been to testify against her, but Jannon said she was mistaken and had only been summoned about stones thrown in the water

third_parties.name: Claudon Houatte

third_parties.name: Two daughters aged 18 and 17

third_parties.context: Acted as intermediary; entered stable where oxen were sick; quarrelled with Didier Villaume's son

third_parties.name: Bernard Rouyer

third_parties.name: Marguerite Alix Thomas
third_parties.context: From St Maurice

third_parties.name: Curien Simonin
third_parties.context: From bois de Mortagne; of 'haulte stature'; named under torture as having been at sabbat; investigation ordered Nov 23

third_parties.name: Mongeote (wife of Jean Jacot Gegoulf)
third_parties.context: Was in such pain cried for three days and nights; Fleuratte touched her and she became ill

third_parties.context: Married daughter who fell ill; Fleuratte visited and gave her honey; died the Sunday after

third_parties.name: Jannon (wife of Jean Jacat Demenge)
third_parties.context: Had dispute with Fleuratte and called her a witch; cow died shortly afterwards

third_parties.name: Chambermaid of Judith femme Nicolas Huguenin
third_parties.context: Touched by Fleuratte on shoulder, calling her 'la grosse demersale'; became ill

third_parties.name: Small shepherdess of Yolent femme Hilaire Mirpot
third_parties.context: Quarrelled with Fleuratte's daughter and told her her mother was a witch

third_parties.name: Servant of Didier Villaume
third_parties.context: Told by Fleuratte that it was well they had acted quickly to cure the child

third_parties.name: Un particulier qui est coustumier de traiter le bestail
third_parties.context: Animal expert who said the bull had an unknown illness and was bewitched

third_parties.name: Wife of Mongel Barbay
third_parties.context: Advised witness 18 to call in Fleuratte; noticed Fleuratte making sign of cross with left hand

third_parties.name: Bartremin Jacquel
third_parties.context: Went with Mongel Barbay and Pierron Biol to confront Fleuratte

third_parties.name: Pierron Biol
third_parties.context: Went with Mongel Barbay and Bartremin Jacquel to confront Fleuratte

third_parties.name: Judict wife of Nicolas Jean Begel
third_parties.context: Healed by Fleuratte using magical prayer for 'prinses de l'air et mal de teste'

third_parties.name: Jannon Ancel
third_parties.context: Healed by Fleuratte using magical prayer for 'prinses de l'air et mal de teste'

third_parties.name: Devil/Persin/petit chouchoux
third_parties.context: Appeared first as hare, then as boy offering money, then as black cat; asked her to believe in him and renounce God; gave her copper jeton instead of franc; disappeared when she wore cross

third_parties.name: Bel Bernard
third_parties.context: Saint at Vic to whom multiple pilgrims were sent by Fleuratte for healing; received living offerings of hens

third_parties.name: St. Maurix
third_parties.context: Saint to whom offerings were made for health of grandson

third_parties.name: St. Hidoult
third_parties.context: Saint to whom offering was made (unsuccessfully) for health of child

third_parties.name: Monsieur St Dele
third_parties.context: Saint to whom cloth was to be sent to see if animal would recover

third_parties.name: Monsieur Saint Desair
third_parties.context: Saint invoked in Fleuratte's healing prayer

third_parties.name: Sieurs Gruyers et Controleurs d'Arches
third_parties.context: Forest officials who issued assignats for marking trees

third_parties.name: Claudon Andreu
third_parties.context: Owner of grange at Sebarup where Claudon Mongin worked

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an exceptionally detailed trial record with 19 witness depositions. Fleuratte was a folk healer who was both feared and sought after for cures. The trial shows classic patterns: long-standing reputation (14 years), quarrels over small economic matters followed by harm, community fear leading to appeasement with gifts of food. She initially confessed to encounter with devil but later retracted; confession was renewed under torture. She was executed by burning on November 10, 1615. The case led to investigation of Curien Simonin whom she named under torture. Notable for detailed healing practices mixing Catholic and folk elements, and extensive catalog of alleged maleficia including human deaths, animal deaths, and illnesses.
